results.abstract: With fewer people and more protocols, the country’s largest museum is ready to welcome visitors again.

results.title: Whitney Cancels Show That Included Works Bought at Fund-Raisers
results.abstract: Black artists objected after they discovered their work had been acquired by the museum through discounted sales meant to benefit charities.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small

multimedia.caption: The Whitney Museum of American Art has canceled an exhibition after artists objected to its purchasing their works at a discounted rate meant for racial justice fund-raisers.

results.title: ‘I May Destroy You’ Imagines a Path Back From Sexual Assault
results.abstract: In Monday’s season finale, Michaela Coel’s summer breakout hit offered some of the most cathartic moments of television I have ever seen.

results.title: Hot 97 Fires Rap Radio Veteran for Ties to Yusuf Hawkins Killing

results.title: Sterling K. Brown and Andre Braugher’s Lives Keep Intersecting
results.abstract: The two actors are Emmy competitors this year, just one example of “so many parallels” between them, Brown said. In a conversation, they discussed cop shows and the pressures of representation.

results.title: ‘Soul!’ Brought Black Culture to TV in 1968. A New Doc Tells Its Story.
results.abstract: “Mr. Soul!” spotlights Ellis Haizlip, the host of a show that gave Stevie Wonder, Wilson Pickett and James Baldwin a platform.

results.title: Orchestras Looking to Broaden Horizons? Start Improvising
results.abstract: Programming works involving improvisation would be one way to encourage ensembles to make classical music more inclusive.

multimedia.caption: Artists like Roscoe Mitchell have wedded their interests in varied forms of composition to their experiences as improvising performers. In their orchestral works, they sometimes ask the musicians to improvise, too.

results.title: How the Hollywood Fix Cornered the Influencer Paparazzi Market
results.abstract: Fletcher Greene, 38, used to photograph all sorts of celebrities. But when the pandemic hit, the A-listers hid while Gen Z’s rising stars stayed in plain sight.

multimedia.caption: Fletcher Greene, 38, is a paparazzo and the creator of the Hollywood Fix, a media brand that has become the go-to source for news about Gen Z celebrities. Here, he shoots a TMZ-style interview with the TikTok star Tony Lopez.

results.title: Istvan Rabovsky, Ballet Dancer Who Defected From Hungary, Dies at 90
results.abstract: A powerful dancer, he and his first wife, the ballerina Nora Kovach, were among the first highly-publicized defectors from the Soviet Bloc.

multimedia.caption: The Hungarian dancers Nora Kovach and Istvan Rabovsky created a sensation with their technical virtuosity and an energetic style unknown to Western audiences.
multimedia.copyright: Maurice Seymour, University at Buffalo Libraries

results.title: Elena Ferrante’s New Novel Is a Suspenseful Story About the Sins of Parents
results.abstract: In “The Lying Life of Adults,” a woman remembers rebelling against her family and befriending a long-estranged aunt.

results.title: Gail Sheehy’s Books Helped Readers Define Their Lives
results.abstract: Ms. Sheehy, a journalist, mapped out the crises one experiences in adult life, offering advice that was both tough and wise.
results.byline: By Tina Jordan and Amisha Padnani

multimedia.caption: The author Gail Sheehy in 1999. Her book “Passages” was considered one of the most influential of modern times.

results.title: Pandit Jasraj, Master Indian Vocalist, Is Dead at 90
results.abstract: Known for his soulful voice and multi-octave range, he was one of the most famous performers in Hindustani classical music.

results.title: Joe Segal, Impresario of Live Jazz for 70 Years, Dies at 94
results.abstract: His Jazz Showcase was a staple in Chicago since 1947, presenting a who’s who of artists, from Charlie Parker to Dee Dee Bridgewater. To the N.E.A., he was a Jazz Master.

multimedia.caption: Joe Segal in 2003 with a placard for a show by the saxophonist Charles McPherson. Mr. Segal discovered and supported numerous jazz artists.

results.title: Gail Sheehy, Journalist, Author and Social Observer, Dies at 83
results.abstract: She looked at what makes public figures tick and, in her “Passages” books, how adults navigate life’s inevitable changes.

multimedia.caption: Gail Sheehy in 1999. She was a lively participant in New York’s literary scene and a practitioner of the creative nonfiction called New Journalism.

results.title: The Trauma of the Civil War Lives On in Faulkner’s Fiction
results.abstract: “The Saddest Words,” by the scholar Michael Gorra, argues that America’s troubled racial past is the central, if often unspoken, theme at the heart of Faulkner’s work.
des_facet: The Saddest Words: William Faulkner's Civil War (Book)

multimedia.caption: “Few historians and fewer novelists of his day saw the hobbling vainglorious past so clearly,” Michael Gorra writes of William Faulkner, “and few of them made slavery so central to their accounts of the war.”
multimedia.copyright: Mario De Biasi/Mondadori, via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: “Few historians and fewer novelists of his day saw the hobbling vainglorious past so clearly,” Michael Gorra writes of William Faulkner, “and few of them made slavery so central to their accounts of the war.”

results.title: Frank Cullotta, Mobster Turned Memoirist and YouTuber, Dies at 81
results.abstract: Mr. Cullotta testified in organized crime cases, and went on to write memoirs, give tours and speak about his life on his YouTube channel, “Coffee with Cullotta.” He died of Covid-19.

multimedia.caption: Frank Cullotta, once a Chicago mobster, found a second calling giving mob history tours. He also consulted on Martin Scorsese’s film “Casino.”

multimedia.caption: Signed copies of “Folklore,” delivered to indie record shops, helped Taylor Swift secure a fourth week atop the Billboard 200 chart.

results.title: Outdoors in Bushwick, Gardens of Theatrical Discovery
results.abstract: Replete with music, masks and vibrant costumes, “Quince” and “Beast Visit” turn urban green spaces into stages for festivity.

multimedia.caption: From left, Camilo Quiroz-Vazquez (writer), Ximena Violante, Quetziquetl Angulo-Alemán, Graceson Abreu-Nunez, Valeria A. Avina, Sara Gutierrez, Livvie Goble in “Quince.”
